subject: Re: [junit] Re: Help plz...
msgSnippet: ... Of course.  But one of the subthreads in this discussion is that comments can be made unnecessary by, for example, appropriate choice of
messageBody:
On Tue, 23 Sep 2003, ssmith12345uk wrote:

> > This concerns software developed by IBM researchers to
> > reduce the size of Java code. One of their tools minimizes the
> length of
> > names where possible (it's not possible where a name is part of a
> > published interface). Using this and other techniques they
> typically
> > shrink Java code by well over 50% for a small one-time cost in
> terms of
> > computer cycles (it takes about 4 minutes to process 3.8 MB of
> code on an
> > 800 MHz PC).
>
> That's an interesting assertion. I'm not sure that I can relate it
> to the presence or absence of comments, particularly since comments
> don't end up in the compiled code.

Of course. But one of the subthreads in this discussion is that
comments can be made unnecessary by, for example, appropriate choice
of variable/method/class/etc names. This is something that we all do, I
imagine.

But the longer and more meaningful the names, the slower the code ;-)

> If this compression of names is
> that beneficial, then it sounds like it should be a part of the
> automated build process i.e.
>
> Source Code In ---> Everything renamed to short names --> Compiler --
> > Result

Agreed. Googling tells me that IBM's software can be found at
http://www.alphaworks.ibm.com/tech/JAX

> > There is a reasonably reliable relationship between code size and
> > speed. Less than half as many bytes typically means software that
> > runs more than twice as fast.
>
> I would have expected that choice of algorithm, correct use of
> buffered I/O and so on would have a larger effect on performance
> than the relative size in bytes of the compiled result. Is the
> article online for us to examine?

It's somewhere on www.acm.org, but I think that you have to be a
member to view it for free. The article is "Extracting Library-Based
Java Applications", authors Frank Tip et al, _Communications of the
ACM_, August 2003, vol 46, no 8.

This is just one of the articles; the entire issue is focused on
program compaction.

However, we are talking partial derivatives here. That is, given
a specific algorithm, use of buffered I/O, etc, if you have twice
as much code to execute it's likely to take twice as long.

> > Sure, but bear in mind the cost of using long names and an expanded
> > class hierarchy to replace comments.
>
> I'm not clear what the cost of using long variable names is. Could
> you go into further detail about what the costs of the above two
> are? I also suspect that if either of these things has a
> significant cost, then we are using wrong tools, or the right tools
> incorrectly.

As I recall, the constant pool is typically around 70% of the size
of a Java .class file and the bytecode something like 14%. A large
part of the constant pool is just names.

I haven't measured these things myself; I am relying upon perhaps
imperfect memory of someone else's work.

If you look at the bytecode of a typical method you can see how
expensive referring to interfaces or in fact anything by name is.
See http://jakarta.apache.org/bcel and especially the bcelifier
for this.

> I must confess, I am definitely one of the 'comment extremely
> sparsely' crowd. What might be interesting is if we perhaps wrote a
> Ruby program to process a Java source tree, replacing the symbols
> with the smallest identifiers possible, unless they are tagged with
> a @published tag for external compatibility reasons. I would expect
> to be able to produce a readable and maintainable program to do this
> with very few comments indeed. I also expect to be able to write a
> program to convert a stack trace back to the original symbols, again
> with very few comments.
>
> Do you think that might be a worthwhile or interesting exercise?

Sure. However, why not just write the thing in Java?

I have in mind doing something like this for a large code set,
probably JBoss.

The object would be an Ant/Maven-compatible tool and a set of publicly
maintained results. Statistics like "the constant pool is X% of JBoss
classes" and "bytecode is Y% of such classes" should be valuable, as
would be benchmarks of performance improvements from shrinking code.

> I can higly recommend 'Refactoring' by Martin Fowler. He has lots
> of great ideas and examples relating to identifying code quality,
> and a few bits on unit testing too.

Noted. ;-)
